snippet: The Office of Congressional Ethics should have a parallel so that complaints against members will be vetted, not quietly buried.
abstract: Editorial contends public's low opinion of Congress has helped to insulate Office of Congressional Ethics from efforts by members of Congress to shut it down; notes office has become credible watchdog of misbehavior by House members, and stands as powerful argument for creating parallel office in Senate.
lead_paragraph: The Office of Congressional Ethics should have a parallel so that complaints against members will be vetted, not quietly buried.

headline.main: The House’s Ethics Lesson for the Senate
headline.print_headline: The House’s Lesson for the Senate
